title: Christian Bassedas
text:
Christian Gustavo Bassedas (born 16 February 1973) is an Argentine former <a href="Association%20football">football</a>er who played as a <a href="defensive%20midfielder">defensive midfielder</a>. 
Bassedas made 267 appearances for <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20V%C3%A9lez%20S%C3%A1rsfield">Vélez Sársfield</a>, giving him the eleventh most appearances in club history. He is currently the head coach of <a href="UAI%20Urquiza">UAI Urquiza</a>.
Career.
Club.
Bassedas is a product of <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20V%C3%A9lez%20S%C3%A1rsfield">Vélez Sársfield</a> youth divisions, club where he debuted professionally on 3 March 1991. He played as a <a href="Sweeper%20%28association%20football%29">sweeper</a> (libero), and was an important part of Vélez most successful years during the 1990s. He won four national championships with the club, and five international (including the <a href="1994%20Intercontinental%20Cup">1994 Intercontinental Cup</a>, where he was a starter in the 2–0 victory over <a href="A.C.%20Milan">A.C. Milan</a>).
In 2000, he joined English <a href="FA%20Premier%20League">FA Premier League</a> club <a href="Newcastle%20United%20F.C.">Newcastle United</a> for £3,500,000. He played for them in the period 2000–2003, though on loan to <a href="CD%20Tenerife">Tenerife</a> briefly during the 2001–02 season. He scored once in the league for Newcastle in a 3–1 defeat at <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea</a> in January 2001.
In 2003, he joined Argentine <a href="Newell%27s%20Old%20Boys">Newell's Old Boys</a>, but after two months of pre-season training he decided to retire from football at the age of 30.
He later worked for <a href="Fox%20Sports%20en%20Latinoam%C3%A9rica">Fox Sports en Latinoamérica</a> as a commentator on <a href="FA%20Premier%20League">FA Premier League</a> matches.
International.
Bassedas played for the <a href="Argentina%20national%20football%20team">Argentine national team</a> during the <a href="1998%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification">1998 FIFA World Cup qualification</a> matches, but was not part of the squad for the World Cup. He also won a silver medal at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201996%20Summer%20Olympics">1996 Olympics</a> and a gold medal at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201995%20Pan%20American%20Games">1995 Pan Americans</a>, where he captained the team.
Management.
At the end of 2008, Bassedas was appointed as sports consultant of <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20V%C3%A9lez%20S%C3%A1rsfield">Vélez Sársfield</a> of the <a href="Argentine%20Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n">Argentine Primera División</a>. His first order of business was to recommend <a href="Ricardo%20Gareca">Ricardo Gareca</a> to fill the coaching spot. He was also essential in the negotiations to bring <a href="Maximiliano%20Moralez">Maximiliano Moralez</a>, <a href="Sebasti%C3%A1n%20Dom%C3%ADnguez">Sebastián Domínguez</a> and <a href="Joaqu%C3%ADn%20Larrivey">Joaquín Larrivey</a> to the club. In his first season with the club, Vélez won the <a href="Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20Argentina%202008-09%23Torneo%20Clausura">Clausura 09</a>.
In November 2015, he was appointed as manager of Vélez Sársfield. He resigned in September 2016, after a 0–3 loss against <a href="Racing%20Club%20de%20Avellaneda">Racing Club</a>, citing the violent reaction Vélez supporters as his reason for leaving.
He was appointed as the head coach of <a href="Club%20Olimpo">Club Olimpo</a> on 20 December 2017.
On 6 October 2018, Bassedas was appointed as the head coach of <a href="UAI%20Urquiza">UAI Urquiza</a>.
